On March 8-10, Mrs. Candice Flatt's ACCEL Academy class went to Louisville to compete in the Kentucky United Nations Assembly or KUNA conference. KUNA is a United Nations simulation competition where students represent a country and debate global issues as that country. This year Adair County represented Brazil and brought home numerous awards such as: Premier Delegation, Outstanding Ambassador (Jeanene Pike), Outstanding Cultural Sign, and Security General for KUNA 2021 (Billy Salmon), which is the top position of the entire conference. KUNA has been around over 100 years, and this is the first time Adair County has had a Secretary General elected to run KUNA. This was a ground breaking year for us, and we can't wait to see what next year holds with Billy Salmon as KUNA's Secretary General. Congrats Billy!

Members of KUNA: Billy Salmon, Emilee Flatt, Jeanene Pike, Hannah Brown, Rachel Brown, Gracelyn Akin, Ashton Flatt, Jonathan Gold, Michael Gold, Ethan Coomer, Lindsey Taylor, Hayden Hancock, and Briley Burns.

post_text: Mrs. Hayes‚Äô 1st grade class at ACPC has been studying text features and the importance of them in nonfiction texts. The class attended ‚Äúmedical‚Äù school and learned all about the text features. The students then were given 8 different patient files that contained people who needed ‚Äúsurgery‚Äù. The students would read the patient file and determine what text feature was needed to make them better. They then had to perform surgery using nonfiction texts. After all the operations were completed, the students had to complete a post-op reports discussing the text feature transplant that was given and the purpose of the text feature when reading nonfiction texts. This was a very exciting, hands-on, real world activity that the students really got involved in. The activity was followed by an assessment that confirmed their knowledge of each text feature.
